Representative_Docs: ['Tosca Theresa Pardini Birth: 1931 Death: 2025 Tosca Theresa Pardini, beloved mother, Nonna, great grandmother, and cherished friend, passed away peacefully on Sunday, November 16, surrounded by the love of her family. On a dark, cloudy day, as the Frank Sinatra song “Fly Me to the Moon” played softly, a single ray of sunshine broke through and gently touched her beautiful face as she took her final breath with her family by her side. She was born at home in San Francisco on May 7, 1931, and she carried the spirit of the city with her throughout her life. Tosca later made her home in Ross, California, where she built a life centered on family, tradition, and enduring love. Tosca met the love of her life, Sergio Pardini, and they were married on February 17, 1952, at Saints Peter and Paul Church in North Beach. For sixty one adventure filled years they were inseparable and shared a deep devotion that guided their lives together. Known for her warmth, elegance, and quiet strength, Tosca created a home where everyone felt welcome. She was deeply proud of her Italian heritage and the traditions she lovingly passed down. Her kindness and grace touched all who knew her. Tosca loved traveling the world with Ser', 'Janet Marie Flores Birth: 1931 Death: 2025 Janet Marie Flores passed away peacefully on November 21, 2025 at the age of 94 surrounded by the love of her family. Jan was born on October 31, 1931 in San Francisco to loving parents Alice Detour and Joseph Hettrick. Jan was a loving mother, grandmother and great grandmother who found her greatest joy in her family. She had a way of making people feel welcomed. She was kind, big hearted, extremely gracious and devoted to those she loved. Her presence will be deeply missed. Jan lived a long life traveling, playing golf, bunco with her friends and one of her greatest talents was to find a treasure at garage sales. In her final years she enjoyed playing penny slots at the casino. The last nine years Jan spent in the loving care of her daughter and son in law. A special thank you to her granddaughter Samantha for making her last days warm, comfortable and full of love. Jan survived by her daughter Tina Schilling (Michael), her grandchildren Michael (Marissa), Paul (Kacie), Samantha (Carlos), and her nine great grandchildren Jackson, Aubrey, Jordan, Mikey, Ellie, Luna, Ryder, Makayla and Stella. And her friends who will forever cherish her memory. Celebration', 'Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser Birth: 1950 Death: 2025 Linda Sue (Jordan) Schlosser March 16, 1950-December 15, 2025 passed away peacefully surrounded by her family at her home in San Pancho, Mexico. She was preceded in death by her father, Wayne Henry Jordan and brother Michael Wayne Jordan. Linda was born and raised in San Rafael, CA and graduated from Terra Linda High School. Linda loved sunshine, warm weather and travel. She was an outstanding cook and loved to entertain. Her great adventure was moving to Mexico, building a wonderful home filled with warmth, family, friends and great meals. She loved traveling throughout Mexico and Italy. Her family requests that gifts in lieu of flowers be made in Linda’s name to St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. Name: 6_family_family members_gifts_friendships
Representative_Docs: ['Asking Eric: Family, friends don’t seem to appreciate time I put into tedious Christmas cookie tradition Dear Eric: My late mother made a special Christmas cookie that required tedious decorating, considering each person’s personal preference for toppings, and giving them as gifts to family and friends. They always had a place of honor on our family Christmas table. When she was no longer able, she gave me the cookie cutter, and my daughters and I took over the family tradition. It takes the three of us several days to make, bake, decorate, package and mail cookies to family members around the country. We enjoy doing it and feel like we’re continuing the fun and festive tradition. However, in recent years, not all of the recipients acknowledge receipt. At some point in their lives, they have all helped Grandma decorate, so they know the time involved. Because of past delivery issues, I track the boxes and inquire if I haven’t heard from them in a couple of days. Last year, one response was “yes we got them.” This feels unappreciative! In the past most would text a picture of their children with the cookies, which we really enjoyed. We rarely see any of them anymore, as they are busy raising their families and don’t live nearby. This seems like a way for us to continue somewhat of a co', 'Asking Eric: Can mom work through tension in son’s relationship with dad so they can celebrate special birthday? Dear Eric: My son is turning 40 on December 22. My husband and I are at a quandary as to how to celebrate him. There have been issues between my husband and him over things from his childhood. We did a special trip for his older brother when he turned 40 and would like to do something special for this son’s 40th as well. Our daughter-in-law has made special plans for him and we are not included. I understand that, but I need some ideas as to how to celebrate this extra special year without rocking the boat. I love my son with all my heart, as I do all my children, and want his 40th birthday to be memorable in a positive way. Any suggestions? – Mom Who Wants to Celebrate Dear Mom: The issues your son and your husband are having may be an obstacle, but they aren’t insurmountable. And the thing that can get them on the path to resolution is the same thing that can get you answers about how to celebrate your son: open communication. It’s not within your purview to try to fix things between them, but you have your own relationship with your son and so I’d encourage you to reach out and tell him what you told me: you want to celebrate him, you know things are difficult, and you’re lookin', 'Asking Eric: After 6 years sober, man is frustrated by his family’s hold on their hurt and distrust Dear Eric: I’ve just turned 40 this past year. The last 15 years I was in a horrible drug addiction. I lied and hurt and did terrible things to a lot of people, especially my family. About eight years ago they officially disowned me. Understandable. I’ve cleaned up and got my act together six years ago. At first, I tried to force my way back into their lives, which all refuted. I lashed out, said horrible things and stopped trying to be in their lives. My mom will stop by on my birthday for 10 minutes or so and drop a card off at Christmas. As for my two older brothers and my father, it’s radio silence. I guess what I’m asking is, what do I do to fix this and fast, as I said I’ve turned 40 this year, my parents are both 70. Time is running out, and I couldn’t imagine living my life without some kind of acceptance from my father. Or knowing he did or does love me. My heart breaks at the thought, but this is a real pickle. How can I fix a problem when the ones I need to fix it with won’t talk to me? Do I just keep ignoring their existence and put on this façade that I don’t care to my wife and 4-year-old son? What picture am I painting to my son, as he’s been guilty by association yo']

Representative_Docs: ['Disagreement Between Two Kidney Function Tests Predicts Serious Health Problems NEW YORK and HOUSTON, Nov. 7, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- A mismatch between two common tests for kidney function may indicate a higher risk for kidney failure, heart disease, and death, a new study shows. Health care providers for decades have measured blood levels of the molecule creatinine to track the rate at which kidneys filter waste from muscle breakdown in the bloodstream. According to more recent guidelines, levels of cystatin C, a small protein made by all cells in the body, can also be used to measure kidney function. Since these two tests are influenced by different factors — including some related to disease or aging — using both markers together can provide a better measure of kidney function and risk of organ failure than either one alone. Led by NYU Langone Health researchers, the new work reveals that many people, especially those who are sick, often have a large gap between the two readings, which may be a signal of future disease. Specifically, the global study shows that more than a third of hospitalized participants had a cystatin C-based readout of kidney function that was at least 30% lower than one based on their creatinine levels. Representative_Docs: ['‘UK public have tougher stance on immigration and diversity than people in US’ People in the UK are less likely than their US counterparts to feel diversity strengthens society and more likely to have tougher attitudes on immigration, according to research. The findings are said to show that a common narrative about Britain being more socially liberal than America does not ring true across all issues. The National Centre for Social Research also found Reform UK voters in Britain were more likely than supporters of President Donald Trump in the US to say immigrants living in their country without permission should not be allowed to stay. While seven in 10 supporters of Mr Trump felt this way, the figure was almost eight in 10 (79%) among Reform followers. The researchers said they wanted to “better understand how public attitudes in the UK compare with those in the US, and the extent of polarisation in the two countries”. Their survey found 42% of people in the UK think there should be legal efforts to deport immigrants living here without permission, compared with just a third (33%) in the US. While almost two-thirds (64%) of respondents in the US felt diversity strengthens society, only around half (49%) of the UK public agreed. Representative_Docs: ['Minnesota high schoolers prepare for once-in-lifetime learning trip to Africa ASHBY, Minn. — There are field trips and there are field trips. Students at Ashby High School are busy raising money and getting ready to pack their bags for a two-week learning experience in South Africa. ADVERTISEMENT When it is below zero, the main street in Ashby, Minnesota, is quiet. Fewer than 500 people call this Grant County town home, but lately the town is busy rallying around a group of high school students. In the basement of Peace Grue Lutheran in the middle of town, five high school students join veteran church quilters in tying quilts that the students will take on their trip to South Africa. "There is a reason the church ladies do this and not the guys," joked Kevin Fick, the girls\' weightlifting coach and organizer of the trip, of tying quilts the students will take with them as gifts.
